As lamentable as the fact is, the end of the year raises
thoughts of one's glorious or inglorious past, promises
for the future and a general evaluation of what one ever
hopes to achieve. It is as important for us at the NewsLetter to do so as it is for any one individual or for
any one government.
As was dramatically pointed out to us a few times
this year, we are in effect the sole voice of the students
readily available to the public. Also, considering the
hoarseness of other student activities and councils, it
seems that the News-Letter is the only effective channel
at Hopkins through which the administration can learn
of discontent and problems which exist among the undergraduates.
Much to the consternation of many segments of
this university, we have indeed been vocal; but it is imperative that we do speak out against possible wrongs,
not only at Hopkins but in our society as well. Our
primary purpose is not change for the sake of change,
but rather to open minds, to make people question themselves and their beliefs, and to inform.
We are not the university's house organ, nor will
we ever let ourselves become that; the alumni Journal
already exists for such a purpose. As one Hopkins alumnus wrote recently. "If it is the truth that makes men
free, surely it is the whole truth, warts and all, and not
some artfully prettied-up version of the lady. Yet it is
the truth with a heavy mask on that the Journal
presents."
We wear no mask. Like liencken, the eminent Baltimore critic and scribe, who loved his city and yet mercilessly attacked its foibles and faults, we love Hopkins.
Our love for the University, although not seemingly
fathomable to many students who only get excited in the
spring (and only until our first lacrosse defeat), expresses itself precisely in our invectives against the
Hopkins.
All universities, like most everything else in this
world, experience periods both a dynamic growth and
rethinking, and of stagnation. Our effort is directed
against stagnation, not only on the part of the University
but also of the students, who can too easily degenerate
into an apathetic and disengaged mass. President Eisenhower has moved Hopkins well out of its post-war morass
by attracting more grants to the University, by forming
new schools and departments, and by increasing the endowment and faculty salaries. We applaud him for what
he has done.
However, Hopkins has responded little to the innovation and up-dating in many areas of the University
which have marked the past decade in higher education.
In a recent speech to "students leaders," Dr. Eisenhower
said that universities which include students into policy
planning and policy decisions are operating on a naive
assumption. Students should have no say in the workings
of the University, he said, for such decisions rest solely
on the Board of Trustees. This reactionary thinking does
not belong in a university founded with a belief in innovation and experimentation.
In attempting to make Hopkins students more concerned not only with the immediate world of Hopkins,
but also with the world which they will enter after graduation, we feel justified in sometimes stepping beyond
the usual "good-taste" boundary. Our readership is hope.
fully more modern and more realistic than one could
find in a non-university environment. What we are saying, in effect, is that a student newspaper, or any newspaper directed toward a privileged and presumably intellectual group of people, must direct and provoke
rather than simply relate news.
It is with pride that we look back at our achievements of the past year. We championed and won the
right of freshmen to entertain girls in their dormitories,
of Negroes to have their hair cut in a local barbershop,
of students to receive discounts on books bought at the
University store. We carried lengthy discussion on complex but much debated questions: Vietnam, the Long
Range Planning Committee's report, the honor system
and possibilities for revitalization, the role of Hopkins
in the Baltimore community, the position of fraternities
as an institution, and our latest discussion of secret
chemical and biological warfare research. These questions are far from resolved, and we shall continue to
discuss them in the future.
What we hope to achieve in the future, and what we
hope to have achieved to some degree this year, is the
establishment of a more involved body of students, faculty and administration, working together through an
effective communications system for the general betterment of the University. As long as people deny the significence of any one group in the University and any
views which may arise out of it, the Hopkins will persist
as a center of ivory-towerities rather than as a forum
for involved, broad-minded and well-informed intellects.

As lamentable as the fact is, the end of the year raises
thoughts of one's glorious or inglorious past, promises
for the future and a general evaluation of what one ever
hopes to achieve. It is as important for us at the NewsLetter to do so as it is for any one individual or for
any one government.
As was dramatically pointed out to us a few times
this year, we are in effect the sole voice of the students
readily available to the public. Also, considering the
hoarseness of other student activities and councils, it
seems that the News-Letter is the only effective channel
at Hopkins through which the administration can learn
of discontent and problems which exist among the undergraduates.
Much to the consternation of many segments of
this university, we have indeed been vocal; but it is imperative that we do speak out against possible wrongs,
not only at Hopkins but in our society as well. Our
primary purpose is not change for the sake of change,
but rather to open minds, to make people question themselves and their beliefs, and to inform.
We are not the university's house organ, nor will
we ever let ourselves become that; the alumni Journal
already exists for such a purpose. As one Hopkins alumnus wrote recently. "If it is the truth that makes men
free, surely it is the whole truth, warts and all, and not
some artfully prettied-up version of the lady. Yet it is
the truth with a heavy mask on that the Journal
presents."
We wear no mask. Like liencken, the eminent Baltimore critic and scribe, who loved his city and yet mercilessly attacked its foibles and faults, we love Hopkins.
Our love for the University, although not seemingly
fathomable to many students who only get excited in the
spring (and only until our first lacrosse defeat), expresses itself precisely in our invectives against the
Hopkins.
All universities, like most everything else in this
world, experience periods both a dynamic growth and
rethinking, and of stagnation. Our effort is directed
against stagnation, not only on the part of the University
but also of the students, who can too easily degenerate
into an apathetic and disengaged mass. President Eisenhower has moved Hopkins well out of its post-war morass
by attracting more grants to the University, by forming
new schools and departments, and by increasing the endowment and faculty salaries. We applaud him for what
he has done.
However, Hopkins has responded little to the innovation and up-dating in many areas of the University
which have marked the past decade in higher education.
In a recent speech to "students leaders," Dr. Eisenhower
said that universities which include students into policy
planning and policy decisions are operating on a naive
assumption. Students should have no say in the workings
of the University, he said, for such decisions rest solely
on the Board of Trustees. This reactionary thinking does
not belong in a university founded with a belief in innovation and experimentation.
In attempting to make Hopkins students more concerned not only with the immediate world of Hopkins,
but also with the world which they will enter after graduation, we feel justified in sometimes stepping beyond
the usual "good-taste" boundary. Our readership is hope.
fully more modern and more realistic than one could
find in a non-university environment. What we are saying, in effect, is that a student newspaper, or any newspaper directed toward a privileged and presumably intellectual group of people, must direct and provoke
rather than simply relate news.
It is with pride that we look back at our achievements of the past year. We championed and won the
right of freshmen to entertain girls in their dormitories,
of Negroes to have their hair cut in a local barbershop,
of students to receive discounts on books bought at the
University store. We carried lengthy discussion on complex but much debated questions: Vietnam, the Long
Range Planning Committee's report, the honor system
and possibilities for revitalization, the role of Hopkins
in the Baltimore community, the position of fraternities
as an institution, and our latest discussion of secret
chemical and biological warfare research. These questions are far from resolved, and we shall continue to
discuss them in the future.
What we hope to achieve in the future, and what we
hope to have achieved to some degree this year, is the
establishment of a more involved body of students, faculty and administration, working together through an
effective communications system for the general betterment of the University. As long as people deny the significence of any one group in the University and any
views which may arise out of it, the Hopkins will persist
as a center of ivory-towerities rather than as a forum
for involved, broad-minded and well-informed intellects.
